DataElement.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma HER2/Neu Status Protein Overexpression Negative Finding Outcome Code Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The coded response indicating a patient meets the eligibility criteria for participation in a clinical trial regarding a negative finding of HER2/NEU protein overexpression.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma HER2/Neu Status Protein Overexpression Negative Finding Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla._The presence or absence of Her2/Neu on a tissue sample._Synthesis of excess polypeptide within the cell. Overexpression is often due to the amplification or deregulation of the gene which encodes the gene product._A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition._The result of an action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Property.preferredName: Her2/Neu Status Protein Overexpression Negative Finding Outcome
Property.preferredDefinition: The presence or absence of Her2/Neu on a tissue sample.:In biology, to make too many copies of a protein or other substance. Overexpression of certain proteins or other substances may play a role in cancer development.:A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.:The result of an action.

Concepts.definition: The presence or absence of Her2/Neu on a tissue sample.
Synthesis of excess polypeptide within the cell. Overexpression is often due to the amplification or deregulation of the gene which encodes the gene product.
A finding of normality following an examination or investigation looking for the presence of a microorganism, disease, or condition.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Created to support Theradex design of CRFs for NCI CCR trials

ReferenceDocuments.name: Is patient's primary and/or m
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is patient's primary and/or metastatic breast tumor negative for HER-2/neu over-expression based on immunohistochemistry (IHC) (0 or 1+, 2+ if Fluorescence In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) test is negative) or FISH (HER2/CEP17 ratio less than 2.0 or less than 4 Her-2/neu signals per nucleus)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is disease, HER2 negative by FISH or IHC staining 0 or 1+ according to NCCN guidelines?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is disease, HER2 negative by FISH or IHC staining 0 or 1+?

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_eCRF_Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Was the tumor determined to be HER2-negative, when assessed by current ASCO/CAP guidelines?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a solid tumor with HER2 positivity as determined by any one or more of the following: (1) HER2 overexpression defined by IHC 3+; (2) ERBB2 amplification by ISH or next-generation sequencing as determined by any CLIA certified lab (3) a known HER2 activating mutation and meets the specific requirements for HER2 status as outlined in section 3.1.2 of protocol?
